Dec 2, 2016

Get SMART With Your Company’s Social Media

A social media presence is practically mandatory for modern businesses. Nearly every company has, at a minimum, profiles on LinkedIn, Facebook, and Twitter. However, it’s not so easy to actually get those profiles to be productive for your business. An effective and consistent social media profile will help you to better connect with your audience and produce more conversions. This post will show you how to build an engaging Social Profile for your company using SMART Goals.

S — Specific

Make your goals as focused as possible. It’s important to know exactly what target you’re trying to hone in on, rather than just hoping to generally improve your social media. Here are some examples:

  • Drive quality Leads.
  • Build your mailing list.
  • Develop your reputation as an expert in your field.
  • Increase likes on the company’s Facebook page.

M — Measurable

Quantify your goals. How will you measure results, and what numbers are you looking for? If we’re trying to increase our Facebook likes, for example, we’ll of course be measuring in terms of total likes, and we just need to set a target number. But how many is the right amount?

A — Achievable

We’d all like to have tens of thousands of likes on all our Facebook page, and millions of followers for or Twitter account, but it’s just not feasible for most businesses. Instead, we need to set achievable goals. Continuing our Facebook example, a reasonable target would be something like increasing the total number of likes on your page from 200 to 250.

R — Relevant

Make sure your goal is relevant to your business and to your target audience. If your ideal demographic doesn’t really spend much time on Twitter, then it doesn’t make much sense to focus your time and resources there. Understand your product and your audience to make informed, strategic decisions about your objectives. We’ll look at that more in upcoming slides.

Building on our running example, a Facebook page is highly relevant for many industries, especially venues that host live events and restaurants. Venues can post up-to-date schedules for their latest shows, and restaurants can easily feature daily menu specials in a convenient place for their audience.

T — Timely

Set an achievable timeframe for each of your goals. Knowing when each goal needs to be accomplished will let you prioritize your social media to-do list, and will help keep you focused on the task at hand.

To sum it all up, each of your SMART goals should look like this: I want to increase our Facebook page’s likes from 200 to 250 by the end of September. Type up your goals in the form of a checklist.

Following these steps is just the beginning. After you set your goals and put them into practice, you’ll need to review your progress and set your next targets. Remember, business is all about iteration!
